front.title: A Clarification about Redirection Support in DNS Queries over HTTPS (DoH) Specification

abstract.t: This document clarifies the support of redirection in the DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) specification.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document clarifies the intent of DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) whether redirection is allowed or not.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Discussion
section.t:
indicates that the support of HTTP redirection is one of DoH design goals (Section 1): "The described approach is more than a tunnel over HTTP. It establishes default media formatting types for requests and responses but uses normal HTTP content negotiation mechanisms for selecting alternatives that endpoints may prefer in anticipation of serving new use cases. In addition to this media type negotiation, it aligns itself with HTTP features such as caching, redirection, proxying, authentication, and compression.
The integration with HTTP provides a transport suitable for both existing DNS clients and native web applications seeking access to the DNS."
Nevertheless, Section 3 of indicates the following: "This specification does not extend DNS resolution privileges to URIs that are not recognized by the DoH client as configured URIs."
This seems like an internal inconsistency of that is worth to be clarified: is redirection allowed or not?

list.t: A DoH client MUST NOT use a different URI simply because it was discovered outside of the client's configuration (such as through HTTP/2 server push) or because a server offers an unsolicited response that appears to be a valid answer to a DNS query.

section.t: A clarification is proposed in . This clarification focuses on a "different URI" that might be discovered while communicating with an HTTP server.

section.title: The Clarification
section.t: OLD: A DoH client MUST NOT use a different URI simply because it was discovered outside of the client's configuration (such as through HTTP/2 server push) or because a server offers an unsolicited response that appears to be a valid answer to a DNS query.

NEW A DoH client MUST NOT use a different URI that was discovered outside of the client's configuration when communicating with HTTP servers (except via HTTP redirection discussed in Section 6.4 of ).
Also, a DoH client MUST ignore an unsolicited response (such as through HTTP/2 server push) that appears to be a valid answer to a DNS query unless that response comes from a configured URI (as described in Section 5.3).
